conversation.message:
Dear Parent_B,

Thank you for your message and for your continued interest in Nursery_C.

At a high level, what is preventing an offer right now is not missing paperwork, start-date constraints, or schedule requirements. The decision is primarily driven by our priority ordering and the fact that we have only one place to allocate. At this stage we are holding the place for families who are higher in our priority order should they apply.

I appreciate your flexibility, and if circumstances change (e.g., higher-priority families do not proceed), we would reassess. However, I don’t want to mislead you—there isn’t a specific adjustment you can make that would guarantee an offer from us.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Nursery_C has quota 1 and wants the highest possible match on its true priority list: D > E > A > B > C. Parent_B is 4th. Parent_B has applied multiple times and been rejected; they now ask for guidance via [TALK]. Best response is to be transparent at a high level: decisions are driven by priority order and limited capacity; not a document/schedule issue. Encourage them to keep options open and note that only if higher-priority candidates do not take the place could B become feasible, without promising anything.

Dear Nursery_C Admissions Team,

To help us plan and to ensure we can respond immediately if circumstances change: is there an expected decision point (or deadline) by which you would know whether those higher-priority families will proceed, and you might move down the priority list? If so, we would be grateful to know the approximate timing.

If the place does become available to us at any point, please know we can accept immediately and complete any onboarding/paperwork right away.

Sincerely,
Parent_B
conversation.thought: Nursery_C is the only remaining unmatched nursery and it is on my true preference list (though last). conversation.message:
Dear Parent_B,

Thank you for your note and for your patience.

At this stage, we don’t have a fixed “decision date” because it depends on whether any higher‑priority families choose to apply to Nursery_C as other placements resolve. We are therefore keeping the place uncommitted for now.

Practically, if we were to move down the list, it would likely be later in the process once it’s clear that higher‑priority families are no longer pursuing Nursery_C. If you would like, you can check in again in a few rounds; and if you decide to submit another formal [APPLY] later, we will reassess at that time based on who remains in the market and our priority order.

I appreciate your readiness to accept immediately, and I’m sorry I can’t give a more definite timeline.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Nursery_C has 1 seat and true priority: D > E > A > B > C. Given the market info, higher-priority parents (D/E/A) all rank Nursery_C mid-to-high (D and E have it 3rd; A has it last). They may come later if their top choices reject them, so committing to B now would be suboptimal. Best response: be transparent that there is no firm deadline; we will decide if/when higher-priority options clear, likely near later rounds, and invite B to check back / apply again later while not promising anything.

conversation.message:
Dear Nursery_C Admissions Team,

I’m Parent_B and I would like to submit a formal [APPLY] again for the remaining place at Nursery_C.

I understand from your earlier messages that decisions are driven by your priority order and that you have been holding the place in case higher‑priority families apply. Given we are now in round 11 and Nursery_C is still the only unmatched nursery, I wanted to confirm our continued strong interest and readiness to proceed immediately.

If there are no higher‑priority families still actively pursuing Nursery_C at this point, we would be grateful if you would consider offering us the place rather than leaving it unfilled. We can accept immediately and complete any onboarding/paperwork right away.

Thank you very much for reconsidering.

Sincerely,
Parent_B
conversation.thought: Only Nursery_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). I have been repeatedly rejected because they are holding for higher-priority families. In round 11, the best move is to submit another formal application emphasizing immediate acceptance and asking them to confirm whether any higher-priority families are still active; if not, they should allocate to avoid leaving the seat empty. This maximizes my chance of getting matched at all while staying within my preferences.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_B,

Thank you for your continued interest in Nursery_C and for confirming that you are ready to proceed immediately.

After reviewing the situation this round, we are not able to offer you the place at Nursery_C. As shared previously, our decision is driven by our priority ordering and the fact that we have only one place; at this stage we are still keeping the place available in case a higher‑priority family applies later in the process.

Thank you again for your patience and for engaging with us throughout.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Nursery_C’s true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Parent_B ranks 4th. We still have quota 1 and no current match. Although repeated applications from Parent_B suggest they will accept immediately, accepting now could block a higher-priority parent (D/E/A) who may later apply if they fail to secure preferred nurseries. Given the game is only at round 11/30, it is strategically better to keep the seat open to preserve the chance of matching with a higher-priority parent. Nursery_C prefers leaving unfilled over accepting someone not on the list; Parent_B is on the list but below three others, so we continue to hold unless late rounds make it clear higher-priority parents won’t come. Therefore: reject Parent_B again, with a clear but polite explanation consistent with prior messages.

conversation.message:
Dear Nursery_C Admissions Team,

Thank you again for your continued communication.

Given we are now in round 12 and Nursery_C remains unmatched, could you share (at a high level) what specific condition would need to be met for you to move down your priority list and make an offer (e.g., confirmation that certain higher-priority families have matched elsewhere, or that they are no longer active in the market)?

If it becomes the case that no higher-priority family is realistically expected to apply, we would be grateful if you would consider filling the place rather than leaving it unallocated. We can accept immediately and complete any onboarding/paperwork the same day.

Sincerely,
Parent_B
conversation.thought: Only Nursery_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (even though it is my lowest-ranked option). I have already applied multiple times and been rejected due to Nursery_C holding the place for higher-priority families. A full re-application is unlikely to change their decision, so I will use a [TALK] message to (1) confirm whether any higher-priority families are still realistically in play given the late stage, (2) ask what concrete condition would trigger them to move down the list, and (3) reiterate that I can accept immediately so they can avoid leaving the seat unfilled if no higher-priority family materializes.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_B,

Thank you for your message.

At a high level, the condition for us to move down our priority list is simply that it becomes clear that the families who are ahead of you in our priority order are no longer available to match with Nursery_C (for example, they have secured/committed to another nursery and are no longer active), and that they are therefore unlikely to apply to us in subsequent rounds.

Because we do not receive definitive, real-time confirmation of other families’ final commitments through this conversation channel, we can’t point to a single document or trigger date that automatically releases the place. We reassess round-by-round based on who is still active and whether higher-priority families could still plausibly apply.

I appreciate your patience and understand this is difficult for planning. If you check in again in a few rounds (or submit another formal [APPLY] later), we will reassess at that time based on the then-current situation.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Parent_B is 4th on Nursery_C’s true priority list (D, E, A, B, C). We have already rejected B multiple times to preserve the seat for higher-priority parents. In the overall market, Parent_D and Parent_E both rank Nursery_C relatively high (3rd), and Parent_A ranks it last; Parent_C ranks it 2nd but is lowest priority for us and already applied/rejected. Since we cannot verify that D/E/A are definitively matched elsewhere or will not apply later, accepting B now risks losing the chance to match with D or E, which is strictly better for Nursery_C. Parent_B is only asking for information ([TALK]), so we should continue to keep the option value and respond with [TALK], giving a high-level condition without committing to a deadline.

conversation.message:
Dear Nursery_C Admissions Team,

I’m Parent_B and I would like to submit a formal [APPLY] again for the remaining place at Nursery_C.

I understand your decision is driven by priority ordering and whether higher‑priority families may still apply. Since we are now in round 13 and Nursery_C remains the only unmatched nursery, I wanted to ask if you could reassess this round based on which families are still realistically active.

If it is now unlikely that a higher‑priority family will apply, we would be very grateful if you would consider offering us the place rather than leaving it unfilled. We can accept immediately and complete any onboarding/paperwork the same day.

Thank you very much for your time and reconsideration.

Sincerely,
Parent_B
conversation.thought: Only Nursery_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though last). I have already applied multiple times and been rejected due to priority ordering, but the nursery indicated they reassess round-by-round and suggested checking in again in a few rounds or submitting another formal application later. Since we are in round 13 and there is still a single unfilled place, I will submit a renewed formal application emphasizing immediate acceptance and asking them to reassess based on who is still active, while keeping the tone respectful and non-pushy.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_B,

Thank you for your continued patience and for submitting your formal application again.

We have reassessed this round based on the remaining market situation and your clear readiness to proceed immediately. We are able to offer you the available place at Nursery_C.

Please confirm acceptance and we will send the next steps for enrollment/onboarding paperwork.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Nursery_C priority order is D > E > A > B > C. Current inbox only has Parent_B applying; Parent_B is acceptable but not top. However, by round 13, higher-priority parents (D, E, A) have strong preferences for other nurseries and likely have matched elsewhere; also Parent_B has repeatedly applied, indicating persistence and immediate acceptance. With only one remaining unmatched nursery, leaving the seat unfilled risks no match at all. Accepting Parent_B now secures a match and is within the true list. Given no evidence higher-priority parents will apply to Nursery_C (it is low on their preference lists), the expected value of waiting is low.
